quiz.title: Discrete vs Continuous Relationships
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3 Quiz 7: Understanding Different Types of Data Relationships
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Discrete and Continuous Data, Function Types

questions.question: What is the key difference between discrete and continuous data?
options: Discrete has gaps between values; continuous can take any value in a range
Discrete is always whole numbers; continuous is always decimals
Discrete data is qualitative; continuous is quantitative
Discrete data tends to be finite; continuous data tends to be infinite
questions.explanation: Discrete data has distinct, separate values (like counting). Continuous data can take any value within a range (like measuring).

questions.question: Which represents discrete data?
options: Number of students in a class
Time taken to run a race
questions.explanation: Number of students is countable (you can't have 25.3 students). The others are measurable quantities that can have fractional values.

questions.question: What type of graph would you use for discrete data?
questions.explanation: Discrete data is shown with separate points since values only exist at specific inputs, not in between.

questions.question: Is the relationship between time and distance traveled by a car discrete or continuous?
options: Both, depending on how you measure
questions.explanation: A car can be at any position at any time, so distance changes continuously with time.

questions.question: Which function would likely model discrete data?
options: $C(n) = 2.50n$ where n is number of movie tickets
$d(t) = 60t$ where t is time in hours
$T(h) = 70 - 2h$ where h is altitude in thousands of feet
questions.explanation: Number of tickets (n) is discrete - you buy whole tickets. Time, radius, and altitude are continuous measurements.

questions.question: Look at the graph. Is it showing discrete or continuous data?
questions.explanation: The graph shows individual points not connected by lines, indicating discrete data.

questions.question: Which is an example of continuous data collection?
options: Counting cars that pass each hour
Recording test scores from a class
questions.explanation: Temperature can be measured at infinitely many moments, making it continuous when tracked frequently.

questions.question: What does a solid line on a graph typically indicate?
questions.explanation: Solid lines suggest the relationship holds for all values in between plotted points, indicating continuity.

questions.question: Cost of mailing packages based on weight is:
questions.explanation: Weight is continuous (can be any value), but postal rates change at specific weights, creating a stepped (discrete) cost function.

questions.question: Why is it important to distinguish between discrete and continuous?
options: It affects how we graph and analyze the data
Discrete data is always more accurate
Continuous data is harder to collect
It doesn't matter - they're treated the same
questions.explanation: Different mathematical tools and representations are appropriate for each type, affecting analysis and interpretation.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You clearly understand discrete vs continuous data and can identify them in various contexts.
scoreMessages.70: Good understanding! Focus on real-world examples and how they're represented graphically.
scoreMessages.50: Developing understanding. Remember: Discrete = countable, separate values. Continuous = measurable, any value in range.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the basics: Countable things (students, cars) are discrete. Measurable things (height, time, temperature) are continuous.
